title: 115_hr2491
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Global Respect Act". Congress acknowledges the fundamental human rights of all individuals, including the rights to life, liberty, security, privacy, and freedom of expression. There is a concerning trend of violence against LGBT individuals globally, with many countries criminalizing same-sex relations. Thousands of individuals face harassment, attack, arrest, and murder based on their sexual orientation or gender identity every year. (6) Perpetrators of crimes against LGBT individuals often go unpunished.
(7) Government officials in various countries promote negative attitudes towards LGBT individuals, leading to violence.
(8) Authorities have been complicit in abuses against LGBT citizens, including arrest, torture, and sexual abuse.
(9) Celebrations of LGBT individuals are often forced underground due to inaction or harassment by officials. Many countries are improving the protection of LGBT individuals' human rights, despite laws criminalizing same-sex relations hindering access to HIV/AIDS treatment and preventive measures. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "foreign person" is defined as per section 595.304 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. The term "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" is defined in section 502B(d)(1) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The terms "person" and "United States person" are defined in sections 591.308 and 595.315 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations, respectively. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION OF FOREIGN PERSONS RESPONSIBLE FOR GROSS VIOLATIONS OF HUMAN RIGHTS. The President must provide a list of foreign persons involved in human rights violations, including torture, prolonged detention without trial, and denial of rights based on sexual orientation or gender identity. The President must update a list of foreign persons involved in human rights violations, including torture and denial of rights. The list must be transmitted in unclassified form, with the option for classified annexes for certain individuals. Guidance on submitting names will be provided by the Secretary of State. The President can include foreign persons in a classified annex if it is crucial for national security, aligns with congressional intent, and is justified despite public information of wrongdoing. In preparing the list required by subsection (a), the President shall consider information from congressional committees, other countries, and NGOs monitoring human rights violations. The unclassified portion of the list will be made public. A foreign person can be removed from the list if the President reports to congressional committees 15 days before the removal. Before the removal of a foreign person from the list, credible information must exist that they did not engage in the activity they were listed for, they have been prosecuted for the activity, or they have shown a significant change in behavior and committed to not engage in the activity again. Requests for removal can be made by the Chairperson or Ranking Member of appropriate Congressional Committees within 120 days. The President must respond to a written request from a congressional committee regarding the status of a foreign person for inclusion on a list. The response can be classified if deemed necessary for national security. If a foreign person is removed from the list, the Chairpersons and Ranking Members must be notified. The President may provide classified information to congressional committees regarding the removal of a foreign person from a list if it is deemed necessary for national security. The President is required to publish the list without regard to confidentiality requirements for visa records. SEC. 5. INADMISSIBILITY OF CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS. Individuals on the list required by section 4(a) are ineligible for US visas and admission. The Secretary of State will revoke visas and the Secretary of Homeland Security will remove ineligible individuals from the US. Waivers for national security interests may be granted by the Secretaries in consultation with the President. Waivers for national security interests may be granted by the Secretaries in consultation with the President, provided that notice and justification are provided to the appropriate congressional committees. The Secretaries may grant waivers for national security interests, with notice and justification required. The timing for notice of certain waivers is specified, and regulatory authority must be established within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The President, through the Secretary of State, must submit an annual report to Congress on the actions taken to implement the Act, including adding or removing foreign persons from the list, and efforts to coordinate with other countries for imposing sanctions. The President must report annually to Congress on implementing the Act, including adding or removing foreign persons from the list and coordinating with other countries for sanctions. Other countries should consider imposing similar sanctions. SEC. 7. DISCRIMINATION RELATED TO SEXUAL ORIENTATION OR GENDER IDENTITY. The Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor designates officers to track violence and restrictions on fundamental freedoms based on sexual orientation or gender identity in foreign countries. Amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for annual country reports on human rights practices. Amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to include reporting on violence and discrimination affecting fundamental freedoms based on sexual orientation or gender identity in foreign countries. This expands the scope of annual country reports on human rights practices. Amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 now require reporting on violations of freedoms of expression, association, and assembly based on sexual orientation or gender identity in foreign countries.
